case.name: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v EDirect Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 65 (12 February 2008)

whether in trade or commerce among the states

trade practices act 1974 , ss. 6 (2), (3), 58 (a), 79 . the defendant carried on a business at southport in queensland which consisted of soliciting orders for books and magazines and then arranging with a business associate in england to place the appropriate orders with the english publishers to supply the person from whom an order had been received. the defendant arranged with certain persons, whom he called "sub-agents", to solicit for orders in various states. each order was paid for by cheque or in cash when it was placed with the sub-agent who then gave the cheques and cash received by him to his "state manager" who deposited such moneys in the defendant's business bank account in the relevant state. the orders were then forwarded to the defendant's place of business at southport. in november 1976 the defendant gave instructions that no orders were to be forwarded to england which meant that money was received over a period of one year but no orders were filled. the informant laid ten informations against the defendant under s. 79 of the trade practices act 1974 ("the act "), alleging contraventions of s. 58 (a) of the act . in respect of each transaction, to which an information related, it was alleged that the defendant accepted money, in the form of a cheque, at the particular place where the contract of sale was made and that these places were situated in either victoria, south australia or western australia.

need to ensure a penalty is " appropriate "

citances.sentence: On the first question, in Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v E-Direct Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 65 (" E-Direct ") (at [21]---[24]), I set out what I considered to be the principles applicable to an application which is consented to by both parties that the Court make certain declarations; that is, what are sometimes referred to as consent declarations. While that decision dealt with proceedings under the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth), as it then was, I consider the principles I outlined are apt for the present proceedings.

24 In regulatory contexts comparable to the present, this Court has informed itself as to those facts necessary for the granting of declaratory relief by reference to agreed facts and indeed the consent of the parties: Bank of Kuwait and the Middle East v Ship MV 'Mawashi Al Gasseem' (No 2) [2007] FCA 815 at [10] ---[16] [2007] FCA 815 ; , 240 ALR 120 at 122---4; Australian Competition & Consumer Commission v Info4PC.com Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1534 at [10] per Nicholson J; Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v EDirect Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 65 at [20] ---[30], ATPR 42---216; Secretary, Department of Health & Ageing v Pagasa Australia Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1545 at [74] ---[79]; Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Goldy Motors Pty Ltd [2000] FCA 1885 at [30], [34], ATPR 41---801.

77 Declarations have thus been made by consent by this Court in the context of a party admitting a contravention of the Trade Practices Act : eg, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission v Info4PC.com Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1534 at [10] per Nicholson J. The authorities and the approach of this Court to the making of declarations by consent have also recently been usefully summarised by Reeves J in Australian Competition & Consumer Commission v EDirect Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 65 at [20] ---[30], ATPR 42-216. See also: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Goldy Motors Pty Ltd [2000] FCA 1885 at [30] , [34], ATPR 41-801.
